title-group.subtitle: The Dynamic Interpersonal and Affective World of Psychopathic High-Security and Detention Prisoners

article-meta.aff: 2The Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim, Norway

author-notes.corresp: Aina Sundt Gullhaugen, St. Olavs University Hospital, Forensic Department Brøset, Center for Research and Education in Forensic Psychiatry, P.O. 1803 Lade, Trondheim N-7440, Norway Email: Aina.Sundt.Gullhaugen@stolav.no

abstract.p: The present study yields an in-depth examination of the interpersonal and affective world of high-security and detention prisoners with possible (Psychopathy Checklist: Screening Version [PCL:SV] ≥ 13) and strong (PCL:SV ≥ 18) indications of psychopathy. A group of male inmates (n = 16) was compared with noncriminal and non–personality disordered controls (n = 35) on measures of self and other (Young Schema Questionnaire–Short Form [YSQ-SF], Inventory of Interpersonal Problems–Circumplex Scales [IIP-C]), and the experience and regulation of affect (Positive and Negative Affect Schedule [PANAS], Emotion Control Questionnaire 2 [ECQ2]). Results confirm the established grandiose, dominant, and callous characteristics of the psychopath (PCL:SV, Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-IV Axis II Disorders [SCID-II], DSM-IV and ICD-10 Personality Questionnaire [DIP-Q], IIP-C), while demonstrating personal distress and important nuances and variations in psychopathic offenders’ interpersonal and affective functioning (YSQ-SF, PANAS, ECQ2, SCID-II, DIP-Q). These preliminary findings support, expand, and challenge the ordinary portrayal of the psychopath and, if replicated in larger samples, point to a need for an expansion or reformulation of the concept, measurement, and treatment of psychopathy.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Research portrays the psychopath as ruthless, shallow, and cold (Hare, 2003), a one-dimensional figure that lacks the extent and depth characterizing normal personalities. The concept of psychopathy originates from the contribution of thinkers rooted in the various disciplines of medicine, philosophy, and law, and is molded by the intellectual grindstone arising between these separate traditions. Since the early beginning, the concept has been plagued by an uncertain diagnostic nomenclature: from an emphasis on moral and sanity to the 20th century’s focus on different types of personality (Arrigo & Shipley, 2001). The current concept of psychopathy draws heavily from Cleckley’s (1941) seminal work The Mask of Sanity. Cleckley’s contribution was further refined and empirically validated by Hare (1985, 1991; Arrigo & Shipley, 2001), whose accomplishment also includes directing the scientific society’s attention toward the interpersonal and affective characteristics of psychopathy. Scholars have debated the clinical and theoretical concept of psychopathy. Although some find the term misleading as it “reifies the disorder” (see Cooke, 2003, p. 260), others find this position hard to defend as “the concept has shown reliability, descriptive validity, and utility in clinical, correctional, and forensic settings,” and as a growing body of research has strengthened the construct and the predictive validity of the concept of psychopathy (Simonsen & Birket-Smith, 2003, p. vii).

During the last decade, researchers “have commented at length on the core interpersonal and affective features of psychopathy” (Frick & Marsee, 2006; Seto & Quinsey, 2006, p. 592) and agree that interpersonally, psychopaths are dominant, forceful, arrogant, and deceptive; affectively, they lack appropriate emotional responses; and behaviorally, psychopaths lack planfulness and are characterized with impulsiveness or diminished control (Cooke, Michie, & Hart, 2006). The Psychopathy Checklist–Revised (PCL-R; Hare, 2003) was developed to identify these traits in a reliable way. However, the inherent nature of any checklist is a compromise between the advantages of fine-meshed assessment and the expense of time. Focusing on the target’s most salient traits increases the efficiency and accuracy of a checklist but comes with the danger of making the erroneous conclusion that this is how the psychopath acts, thinks, and feels all the time. Leaning on Hare (1996), Shipley and Arrigo (2001) argued that the need for statistical rigor steered the diagnostic community away from the internal processes of the psychopath, so that better agreement might be reached on the person’s observable behaviors. The PCL-R (Hare, 2003) is largely based on Cleckley’s (1941) clinical descriptions of the psychopath and addresses both the personality and behavioral manifestations of psychopathy but does not directly assess levels of anxiety and fear (Hale, Goldstein, Abramowitz, Calamari, & Kosson, 2004). As a consequence, important nuances in psychopaths’ everyday functioning might be lost.

Depending on theoretical adherence, personality can be described both as a dynamic set of processes (the psychodynamic tradition; see Westen, Gabbard, & Ortigo, 2008) and as stable and enduring traits (the five-factor theory of personality; McCrae & Costa, 2008). The current concept of psychopathy rests on the latter tradition. Cleckley (1941) noted the restricted range of affective reactions found in psychopaths, and research has demonstrated correspondence between these traits in early adolescent and adult psychopathy measures (Lynam, Caspi, Moffitt, Loeber, & Stouthamer-Loeber, 2007). Finally, psychopathy (and personality disorder per se) is listed as a historical and largely static risk factor, and not as a clinical or changeable variable (Douglas & Skeem, 2005) in acknowledged risk assessment instruments (see The Historical- Clinical-Risk Management- 20 [HCR-20]; Webster, Douglas, Eaves, & Hart, 1997). Even though a few studies have reported evidence that therapy can be beneficial in reducing risk of recidivism in some psychopathic offenders (e.g., Olver & Wong, 2009), pronounced pessimism pervades attitudes toward finding remedy (Gacono, Nieberding, Owen, Rubel, & Bodholdt, 1997; Salekin, 2002) for the interpersonal and affective core of psychopathy (Cook, Michie, Hart, & Clark, 2005; Schrum & Salekin, 2006).

In the subsequent years, progress in risk assessment followed the shift from a predominantly static focus (dangerous/not dangerous), toward a more dynamic approach specifying variable factors that contribute to specific threats (Douglas & Skeem, 2005; Pedersen, Rasmussen, & Elsass, 2010). Similarly, static and dynamic perspectives on personality (the state-trait distinction; Allen & Potkay, 1981) may represent separate levels of measurement, which leaves personality disorder symptoms rigid yet active. Acknowledging that certain factors are subject to modification marks the beginning of an understanding that is more ecologically valid and better suited to treatment (Strand, Belfrage, Fransson, & Levander, 1999, cited in Nonstad & Webster, 2011). Consequently, there is a time to focus on traits (easy to predict, protective purposes) and a time for asserting a broader and perhaps more situation-specific focus that is not so easy to predict but may eventually lead to a better understanding of the concept of psychopathy.

Assessing potential dynamic characteristics of the psychopath requires an understanding of how such attributes could be manifested in the psychopathic individual and measures designed to calibrate diverse qualities and dynamic patterns in psychological functioning. The International Classification of Diseases–10 (ICD-10; World Health Organization [WHO], 1993) general criteria for personality disorder describes four aspects of human functioning where abnormalities of the personality can be observed: (a) cognition (ways of perceiving and interpreting things, people, and events; forming attitudes and images of self and others), (b) affectivity (range, intensity, and appropriateness of emotional arousal and response), (c) control over impulses and gratification of needs, and (d) manner of relating to others and of handling interpersonal situations. These are higher order variables, prior to observable behavior or specific symptoms, inherently dynamic or active in describing internal process (perceiving and interpreting, forming attitudes and images) and organization (structuring self and other, impulse and affect control) in continued maintaining and adaption to experiences (relating to others, handling interpersonal situations). Clinical instruments targeting internal process and a fuller range of interpersonal and affective traits, which are regularly applied in other patient populations, can be used to test potential variations or dynamic patterns in psychopathic offenders’ interpersonal and affective functioning. According to the ICD-10 general criteria for personality disorder (WHO, 1993), measures targeting cognition, emotions, control, and interpersonal relationships are of interest in this matter.

Our research question is as follows: Is the psychopath more than the persistent callous, grandiose, and ruthless characteristics that we usually see? We hypothesise that measures targeting a fuller range of interpersonal and affective qualities will demonstrate important nuances in psychopathic functioning.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: From the 2008 male Norwegian high-security prison and detention population (Ringerike, Ila, and Trondheim prisons; n = 225), 189 individuals (84%) met the language requirements of the study. From these, a conjoint sample of 30 offenders (15.87%) volunteered to participate in the study. In this initial sample, 18 offenders (60%) completed all measures, from which 16 individuals were selected on the basis of scoring ≥13 (recommended cutoff for possible psychopathy; n = 5) or ≥18 (strong indication of psychopathy; n = 11) on the Psychopathy Checklist: Screening Version (PCL:SV; Hart, Cox, & Hare, 1995).

Ringerike prison is a high-security institution with 160 inmates. Prisoners represent an elevated risk for violence, criminality, and escape, and serve long sentences. Ila and Trondheim prisons accommodate the male detention population (n = 65). Detention prisoners are judged by court as dangerous in a way that requires special precaution, compared with normal sentencing. Detention prisoners are possibly facing lifelong incarceration, and subject to extensive investigation and intervention before being considered for release.

In all prisons, individuals refused participation due to insecurities about confidentiality, health issues, language difficulties, and lack of endurance to the task. In Ringerike prison, individuals also refused participation due to strict procedures for physical examination in connection with visitation.

From the 2007/2008 male undergraduate and graduate psychology student populations at the Norwegian University of Science and Technology (n = 250), 46 individuals (18.4%) volunteered to participate in the study. From this initial sample, 35 noncriminal and non–personality disordered—according to the Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-IV Axis II Disorders (SCID-II; First, Spitzer, Gibbon, & Williams, 1994)—individuals completed all measures (76.1%) and were included as controls. The PCL:SV was not completed in this sample due to the absence of personality disorders, as measured with the SCID-II (First et al., 1994). Table 1 describes demographic and clinical characteristics of offenders scoring ≥13 (n = 16, mean age = 37.57, SD = 10.82) and ≥18 (n = 11, mean age = 34.64, SD = 12.21) on the PCL:SV, and controls (n = 35, mean age = 23.34, SD = 5.35).

sec.p: Individuals included in the study group (n = 16, 8% of the study population) were nondifferent from noncompleters (n = 14) in the initial sample (n = 30, 15.87% of the total study population) with regard to attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), substance abuse, and Axis I and II disorders.

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: Due to the comprehensiveness of the study (which included more instruments than the measures reported in this article; see Gullhaugen & Nøttestad, in press), the PCL:SV (Hart et al., 1995), and not the PCL-R (Hare, 2003), was used to assess psychopathy in the Norwegian male detention and high-security population. The PCL:SV is a 12-items checklist found to be empirically and conceptually related to the current golden standard for measuring psychopathy, the PCL-R (Cooke et al., 1999; Cooke & Michie, 2001; Hare, 1996). The PCL:SV is shorter and requires less collateral information than the PCL-R. The PCL:SV was rated retrospectively (see Laurell & Dåderman, 2007) on the basis of information from a diagnostic interview and self-report measures. Each of the 12 criteria was scored numerically for its definitive (2) and possible (1) presence, and absence (0). According to the manual, the recommended cutoff score for possible psychopathy is ≥13. Scores ≥18 are strong indications of psychopathy. An interrater reliability analysis using the Kappa statistic was performed to determine consistency among raters. The interrater reliability between the first author and another clinical psychologist on the different items was found to have substantial to perfect agreement (Cohen’s κ = 0.770-1.00, p < .000).

sec.title: Diagnostic measures
sec.p: The SCID-I (First, Spitzer, Gibbon, & Williams, 1997) and SCID-II (First et al., 1994) are diagnostic interviews measuring symptom and personality pathology according to the polythetic diagnostic criteria of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (4th ed.; DSM-IV; American Psychiatric Association [APA], 1994). Each criterion is scored numerically for its definitive (3) and possible (2) presence, and absence (1). Cutoff scores are in accordance with the diagnostic manuals. Before examining the study sample, interrater reliability between the first author and a graduate student in clinical psychology on SCID-I and II was calculated in controls (n = 34), with substantial to perfect agreement (Cohen’s κ = 0.93-1.00, p < .001).

The DSM-IV and ICD-10 Personality Questionnaire (DIP-Q; Ottosson et al., 1995) is a valid and reliable self-report measure (Ottosson et al., 1998; Ottosson, Grann, & Kullgren, 2000) of DSM-IV and ICD-10 personality disorders. A total of 135 personality disorder items and 11 items measuring subjective distress are scored as present or not, with cutoff scores according to the diagnostic manuals. In addition, 5 items measure global assessment of functioning. The overall DIP-Q scale was found to be highly reliable (12 items; α = .848). Figure 1 displays correspondence between SCID-II and DIP-Q ratings of psychopathic offenders. Personality disorder symptoms were not found in controls.

caption.p: SCID-II and DIP-Q ratings of offenders with possible or strong indications of psychopathy (n = 16)
Note: SCID-II = Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-IV Axis II Disorders; DIP-Q = DSM-IV and ICD-10 Personality Questionnaire; PCL:SV = Psychopathy Checklist: Screening Version.

sec.p: ADHD was rated with the research criteria for F90 Hyperkinetic disorder (WHO, 1993). The F90 criteria assess attention deficit (nine items), hyperactivity (five items), and impulsivity (four items) as well as four general criteria. Each item is scored as present or not. Cutoff scores are in accordance with the diagnostic manuals. Before examining the study sample, raters agreed on all ADHD evaluations in controls.

sec.title: Interpersonal measures
sec.p: The Inventory of Interpersonal Problems–Circumplex Scales (IIP-C; Soldz, Budman, Demby, & Merry, 1995) is a valid and reliable (Monsen, Hagtvet, Havik, & Eilertsen, 2006) self-report measure of interpersonal problems. Each of the 64 items is scored according to a 5-point Likert-type scale. Subscales are as follows: Vengefulness, Callousness, Socially Avoidant, Low Self-Assertance, Easy to Exploit, Exaggerated Care, Invading, and Dominance. Subscales were computed as the arithmetic mean of all data points contributing to each scale. The overall scale was highly reliable (8 items; α = .886).

Young Schema Questionnaire–Short Form (YSC-SF; Young, 1998) is a valid and reliable (Lee, Taylor, & Dunn, 1999; Schmidt, Joiner, Young, & Telch, 1995) 75-items self-report measure of early maladaptive schemas, or “broad, pervasive themes regarding oneself and one’s relationship with others, developed during childhood, elaborated throughout one’s lifetime, and dysfunctional to a significant degree.” Subscales are as follows: Emotional Deprivation, Abandonment/Instability, Mistrust/Abuse, Social Isolation/Alienation, Defectiveness/Shame, Failure, Dependence/Incompetence, Vulnerability to Harm or Illness, Enmeshment/Undeveloped Self, Subjugation, Self-Sacrifice, Emotional Inhibition, Unrelenting Standards/Hyper Criticalness, Entitlement/Grandiosity, and Insufficient Self-Control/Self-Discipline. Each item is scored according to a 6-point Likert-type scale. Scores for each schema are found by counting the total number of items within each schema rated either 5 or 6. The YSC-SF overall scale was found to be highly reliable (15 items; α = .924).

sec.title: Measures of affect
sec.p: The Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS; Watson, Clark, & Tellegen, 1988) is a valid and reliable (Crawford & Henry, 2004; Watson et al., 1988) self-report measure of 20 distinct emotions forming a positive and a negative experiences subscale. Emotions are scored according to a 5-point Likert-type scale, “usually” and “last week.” Subscales were computed by adding items belonging to each scale. The PANAS negative experience subscales demonstrated high internal consistency (10 items; α = .884 “usually” and .871 “last week”). The positive experience subscales were equally good (10 items; α = .879 “usually” and .866 “last week”).

The Emotion Control Questionnaire 2 (ECQ2; Roger & Nesshoever, 1987) is a 56-items valid and reliable (Roger & Najarian, 1989; Roger & Nesshoever, 1987) self-report measure of four subtypes of affective control: Affective Rehearsal (degree of pondering over emotional activating events), Emotional Inhibition (the tendency to suppress expression of emotions), Aggression Control (inhibition of aggression, independent of general emotional constraints), and Benign Control. Each item is scored as present or not. Consistent with Roger and Nesshoever (1987) who constructed and validated the ECQ2 scale for measuring emotion control in university students, Cronbach’s alpha for the overall scale was low (4 items; α = .249, and α = .323 in controls), which according to the authors is to be expected in a scale with a multidimensional orthogonal structure. Unlike Roger and Nesshoever and Roger and Najarian (1989) who reported satisfactory alpha coefficient for all subscales (in university students), we found that Cronbach’s alphas for the four subscales in offenders were Affective Rehearsal (14 items, α = .835), Emotional Inhibition (14 items, α = .783), Aggression Control (14 items, α = .258), and Benign Control (14 items, α = .335). Alpha levels in controls were .745, .551, .494, and .419, respectively. In the rest of the article, we will not discuss subscales with an alpha less than .70.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: Prior to the collection of data, all prisoners and relevant staff were given a verbal and written orientation about the study and the methods used. After having received the information, prisoners were given 1 week to consider participating in the study. Clinical interview and testing took from a little more than 1 hr to approximately 5 hr, depending on the clinical picture and how much the individual was able or willing to reveal. After completing tests and clinical interview, questionnaires estimated to require an effort of about 2 hr were handed out for independent work.

Of importance, interviewers had no access to previous reports of psychopathy or other study variables in the study sample. One of the raters knew the objectives of the study but not the groupings of the participants at the time of collecting and rating the data. PCL:SV rating was based on clinical interview and self-rating measures, to minimise subjective interpretation and evaluate the correspondence between self-report measures and diagnostic interview (Figure 1). Study variables (interpersonal and affective measures) were questionnaires and hence not confounded by raters.

Offenders scoring in the range of possible psychopathy (PCL:SV ≥ 13, range = 13-23, n = 16) were compared with non–personality disordered and noncriminal controls (n = 35) on measures targeting affective and interpersonal functioning. In addition, we compared a subsample of offenders with strong indication of psychopathy (PCL:SV ≥ 18, range = 18-23, n = 11) to the above-mentioned controls.

sec.title: Data Analysis
sec.p: Data analysis was conducted in PASW18. We used nonparametric statistics (independent samples Mann–Whitney U test) on nominal and ordinal variables, and additionally explored potential between-groups differences on some of the variables with parametric statistics (independent-sample t test). Due to the small sample sizes, descriptive statistic was applied to describe patterns in data. Interrater reliability was calculated with Cohen’s kappa, whereas Cronbach’s alpha was computed to control the internal consistency of self-report measures. Correlation was used to describe trends in variables targeting past (last week) and continued (usual) characteristics.

sec.title: Diagnostic Measures
sec.p: SCID-II (First et al., 1994) and DIP-Q (Ottosson et al., 1995) ratings of personality disorder diagnoses and criteria in psychopathic offenders shared a common trend (Figure 1).

sec.title: Interpersonal Measures
sec.p: Scores on the IIP-C (Soldz et al., 1995) revealed that offenders scoring in the range of possible and strong indications of psychopathy (PCL:SV) were significantly higher on vindictive, cold, socially avoidant, and domineering characteristics than non–personality disordered and noncriminal controls (Table 2).

caption.p: Self-Reported Interpersonal Problems (IIP-C) in Offenders Scoring in the Range of Possible Psychopathy (PCL:SV ≥ 13, n = 16) and Offenders With Strong Indications of Psychopathy (PCL:SV ≥ 18, n = 11) Compared With Unmatched Controls (n = 35)

fn.p: Note: IIP-C = Inventory of Interpersonal Problems–Circumplex Scales; PCL:SV = Psychopathy Checklist: Screening Version.

sec.p: Scores on the YSQ-SF (Young, 1998) revealed that offenders scoring in the range of possible and strong indications of psychopathy (PCL:SV) were significantly more disconnected and rejected (emotional deprivation, mistrust/abuse, social alienation/isolation, defectiveness/shame), had more impaired autonomy and performance (dependence/incompetence, vulnerability to harm/illness, enmeshment/undeveloped self), had overvigilance and inhibition (emotional inhibition), and had impaired limits (entitlement/grandiosity) than non–personality disordered and noncriminal controls. Offenders scoring ≥13 on the PCL:SV were significantly higher in number than offenders scoring ≥18 on abandonment and failure, whereas offenders with strong indications of psychopathy scored significantly higher on subjugation of needs and insufficient self-control (Table 3).

caption.p: Early Maladaptive Schemas (YSQ-SF) in Offenders Scoring in the Range of Possible Psychopathy (PCL:SV ≥ 13, n = 16) and Offenders With Strong Indications of Psychopathy (PCL:SV ≥ 18, n = 11) Compared With Unmatched Controls (n = 35)

fn.p: Note: YSQ-SF = Young Schema Questionnaire–Short Form; PCL:SV = Psychopathy Checklist: Screening Version.

sec.title: Affective Measures
sec.p: Scores on the PANAS (Watson et al., 1988) revealed that offenders scoring in the range of possible and strong indications of psychopathy reported significantly higher levels of usual negative feelings, hostility, irritability, and shame than non–personality disordered and noncriminal controls (Table 4). However, with most positive and negative emotions, no significant differences existed between the two study samples and controls (not included in Table 4). Compared with controls, offenders scoring ≥13 on the PCL:SV were significantly higher in number than offenders scoring ≥18 with Negative Emotions Last Week, Feeling Upset, and Being Interested Usually. Offenders with strong indications of psychopathy scored significantly higher on Being In Need Usually, and General Positive Emotions, Being Interested, Enthusiastic, and Alert Last Week.

caption.p: Significant Differences in Emotions (PANAS) in Offenders Scoring in the Range of Possible Psychopathy (PCL:SV ≥ 13, n = 16) and Offenders With Strong Indications of Psychopathy (PCL:SV ≥ 18, n = 11) Compared With Unmatched Controls (n = 35)

fn.p: Note: PANAS = Positive and Negative Affect Schedule; PCL:SV = Psychopathy Checklist: Screening Version.

sec.p: Offenders scoring in the range of possible and strong indications of psychopathy experienced about the same amount of negative emotions over time (usually and last week; r = .597, p = .05, two-tailed). A correlation of the subscales Positive Feelings Usually and Last Week was nonsignificant, indicating variance in Positive Emotions.
Offenders scoring ≥13 on the PCL:SV are characterized with rumination as a strategy for emotional control (Table 5).

caption.p: Emotional Control (ECQ2) in Offenders Scoring in the Range of Possible Psychopathy (PCL:SV ≥ 13, n = 16) and Offenders With Strong Indications of Psychopathy (PCL:SV ≥ 18, n = 11) Compared With Unmatched Controls (n = 35)

fn.p: ECQ2 = Emotion Control Questionnaire 2; PCL:SV = Psychopathy Checklist: Screening Version.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We asked, “Is the psychopath more than the persistent callous, grandiose, and ruthless characteristics that we usually see?” Results confirm the established callous, grandiose, and dominant characteristics of the psychopath, and comorbid personality disorder ratings (mostly avoidant, compulsive, narcissistic, paranoid, and emotionally unstable traits) that are pretty much in line with what we already know (Decuyper, De Fruyt, & Buschman, 2008; Hildebrand & de Ruiter, 2004). However, the academic or conceptual implications of parallel observations of psychopathy and comorbid personality disorder have perhaps not been thoroughly discussed.

The DSM-IV (APA, 1994) and the ICD-10 (WHO, 1993) specific criteria for most personality disorders describe various types of personal distress (e.g., “excessive efforts to avoid abandonment,” “persistent and pervasive feelings of tension and apprehension”). Psychopaths’ lack of the kind of personal distress that typically drives treatment engagement (Galietta, Finneran, Fava, & Rosenfeld, 2010) has been a hallmark in clinical descriptions of psychopathy (see Cleckley, 1941). If PCL-R psychopaths can be diagnosed with comorbid personality disorders normally associated with personal distress (e.g., avoidant, paranoid, and emotionally unstable traits), then we can conclude that unless the investigation is flawed, the psychological functioning of the psychopath is not purely shallow or cold. Repeated findings of this type should encourage discussion about the validity of the current concept of psychopathy. Furthermore, diagnostic co-occurrence may indicate a common, underlying pathology (Widiger, 2006) and the advantage of a dimensional (psychopathy is on a continuum with normal personality functioning within the general population; Coid & Yang, 2008) rather than a categorical (psychopaths are fundamentally different from others and lack basic attributes such as empathy and guilt, which are essential for normal personalities; Coid & Yang, 2008) understanding of psychopathy. Ultimately, observations of personal distress could facilitate treatment, at least theoretically. A practical tip would be to pick the treatment intervention of choice on the basis of comorbid disorders’ diagnostic criteria specifying the direction of vulnerability and pain in each offender.

Results further demonstrate new aspects of psychopathic offenders’ affective and interpersonal functioning. We found that offenders with possible and strong indications of psychopathy are characterized with negative emotions such as hostility, irritability, and shame, and with positive emotions that varies over time. On most emotions, psychopaths were nondifferent from controls, including positive feelings of being enthusiastic, inspired, and strong. Also, more than half of the offenders scoring in the range of possible and strong indications of psychopathy are diagnosed with affective problems, and about 37% have a diagnosable anxiety disorder. These results are incongruent with Cleckley’s (1988) description of general poverty in major affective reactions and support the dimensional approach to understanding psychopathy. Also, offenders scoring above the designated cutoff for possible psychopathy to a larger degree report using affective rehearsal strategies than non–personality disordered controls. Intrinsic pondering over emotional activating events (active, dynamic activity) may leave the individual with an unempathic and callous appearance (static, stable trait), illustrating the importance of investigating both state and trait levels when researching the psychological functioning of offenders with possible and strong indications of psychopathy.

Interpersonally, offenders scoring in the range of possible and strong indications of psychopathy are characterized with expectations that their need for security, safety, stability, nurturance, empathy, sharing of feelings, acceptance, and respect will not be met in a predictable manner (the disconnection and rejection schema modes). Despite their pronounced interpersonal insecurities, more than 50% of the offenders chose to stay in an intimate relationship. Furthermore, offenders report expectations about themselves and the environment that interferes with their perceived ability to separate, survive, function independently, or perform successfully (impaired autonomy and performance schema mode). Finally, offenders showed deficiency in internal limits, responsibility to others, and long-term goal orientation (impaired limits schema mode).

The observation of different measurement levels, or finding psychological correlates (“under the surface activity”) to psychopathic behavior, opens up for a discussion of “what kind of problem psychopathy really is” (which is also the case when finding biological or physiological correlates). Results indicate that behind dissocial behavior and callous traits lay expectations about self and other and affective experiences that seem to interfere with the maintenance of personal and professional relationships. From the field of developmental psychology, we know that interpersonal and affective functioning is “tightly knitted.” Attachment figures represent the child’s most secure emotional base (Brisch, 2002), and some researchers have argued that attachment pathology might serve as an “index of emotional regulation” (Babcock, Jacobson, Gottman, & Yerington, 2000, cited in Meloy, 2003). Recent studies (Franks, Sreenivasan, Spray, & Kirkish, 2009; Young, Justice, & Edberg, 2010) have demonstrated poor emotional modulation and low attachment capacity in male prison inmates scoring above the cutoff for severe psychopathy. As a consequence, observations of callousness (trait level) and difficulties with affect regulation (state level) could indicate attachment pathology at the heart of psychopathy. This seems applicable to the personal distress and interpersonal dynamics and dilemmas reported by the psychopathic offenders included in the present study. These past and present findings are in accordance with the deviant self- and affect regulation accompanying the pathologically developed “object relations” or “internal working models” described in object relation (St. Claire, 2000) and attachment theory (Arrigo & Griffin, 2004), which adds construct validity to the PCL:SV (measure) from a psychodynamic point of view (theoretical concept).

Research applying the five-factor model of personality (McCrae & Costa, 2008) finds that psychopaths are less agreeable, conscientious, anxious, depressed, vulnerable, and warm, and with more assertiveness, angry hostility, and impulsiveness than most people (Decuyper et al., 2008), which adds to the preservation of the current concept of psychopathy. The tension between the different approaches to personality (the five-factor static model and the psychodynamic view of personality) is perhaps at its strongest at the conceptual level when it comes to psychopathy. Real-life practical problems, such as risk assessment and therapy, could focus on traits and intra- or interpersonal process, respectively. According to Serin and Brown (2000, p. 255), “multimethod assessment is recommended given that not every tool is applicable in every situation for every offender (Hart, 1998), and in addition to the PCL-R, the consideration of additional static and true dynamic risk factors is recommended”. The primary gain from the dynamic approach is perhaps the identification of (inter-) personal distress that seems to lack in static descriptions of psychopathy. Static and dynamic approaches to psychopathy seem to complement each other, a finding that may be of value in the general debate about personality.

Results further challenge the concept of primary (severe; constitutional) versus secondary (moderate; disturbance based on early psychosocial learning) psychopathy (Karpman, 1941, cited in Poythress & Skeem, 2006), in that offenders scoring in the range of possible (or secondary) and strong indications of (or primary) psychopathy are largely characterized with the same affective and interpersonal pathology that historically has been reserved for individuals with lower levels of (or secondary) psychopathy. This was also reported in Coid and Ullrich (2010) who compared subgroups of prisoners with antisocial personality disorder above and below the cutoff for psychopathy and found no differences in demography, Axis I comorbidity, and treatment-seeking behavior. On some variables in the present study (e.g., “guilt,” “subjugation of needs,” and “being in need usually”), offenders with strong indications of psychopathy scored higher than the sample including individuals scoring in the range of possible psychopathy. Lack of guilt has been a hallmark of psychopathy, and findings that contrast such important aspects of a concept or theory must undergo further investigation. Could it be that when answering this question in solitude (where nothing much is gained from presenting a careless face), some psychopaths do care? However, results also support the concept of primary and secondary psychopathy, as offenders scoring ≥13 on the PCL:SV confessed to significantly more feelings of being abandoned, upset, and a failure, and rumination as a means for affective control, than offenders scoring in the range of strong indications of psychopathy. Still, this does not change the utility of a dimensional approach to psychopathy, as variations in symptoms should be expected within a continuum or total range of personality functioning.

This study’s results warrant attention for adding to the understanding of the internal world of the psychopath and for strengthening the “not” argument in the interminable “is psychopathy an all or nothing construct or not.” Is the psychopath attempting to satisfy basic needs for relationship and autonomy through organization and regulation of proximity and affect? How to approach a detached, rejected, and impaired versus a dissocial individual? Different approaches yield different strategies and answers. There is a time to focus on traits and a time for focusing on intra- and interpersonal process. This study’s preliminary results indicate that the psychopath’s ruthless, callous, and dissocial behavior has psychological correlates and that some psychopaths take interest in displaying them.

sec.title: The Strengths of the Present Study
sec.p: Our main goal with the present study was to illustrate nuances in the psychopath’s interpersonal and affective functioning. The present study makes use of well-known clinical measures, often applied in other patient populations, to investigate affective and interpersonal characteristics beyond the established measurement of psychopathy. Self-report data were compared with information derived from a diagnostic interview, to control for the pitfalls of relying on self-report and interview measures only. The scoring of the PCL:SV on the basis of diagnostic interview and self-report measures is, as far as we know, a new approach to administering the PCL:SV but follows in the tradition of exploring new ways to collect PCL data (Laurell & Dåderman, 2007).

Despite the small number of participants, the broad approach of the present study (several time-consuming measures) secures a nuanced portrayal of individuals that are most often described according to their most salient traits. The samples sizes would probably have been higher had the study’s scope been more narrow but then important information might be lost.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: The small sample sizes complicates generalisation and is an apparent limitation to the present study. The preliminary results need to be modified according to further research using larger sample sizes to investigate interpersonal and affective variations in psychopathic offenders. Larger samples could have equated or reduced the data and identified patterns not visible in small samples. A comparison of psychopaths with non–psychopathic personality controls or symptom-disordered controls would have provided additional information about the concept of psychopathy in contrast to symptom and personality pathology in general.

Measures were demonstrated to be reliable, except with regard to the low Cronbach’s alpha levels on the Aggression Control and Benign Control subscales of the ECQ2 in offenders and controls (university students). This could be a result of the low sample sizes in the present study, as high alpha levels are reported in university students described in the earlier studies mentioned above. We have been able to localize one earlier study applying the ECQ2 to offenders (McDougall, Venables, & Roger, 1991), unfortunately without reporting internal consistency data. Finally, the present study did not include a lie or social desirability scale. Future research could include this for additional precautions.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p:
Preliminary results support, expand, and challenge the ordinary portrayal of the psychopath by confirming the established callous, grandiose, and dominant characteristics of the psychopath, by adding construct validity to the PCL:SV from a psychodynamic point of view and by demonstrating personal distress and affective and interpersonal dynamics and dilemmas, the identification of which depends on measures that are able to calibrate a fuller range of interpersonal and affective qualities. If replicated in larger samples, this could indicate a need for a reformulation of the concept, measurement, and treatment of psychopathy. We conclude with Gunn (2003),
When we can understand the structural pathology of traits such as impulsivity and the developmental path to ‘manipulative behavior’ (whatever that is), we will become very uninterested in psychopathy, and we will be of greater use to a group of unhealthy patients who are otherwise outside the current framework of medicine. (p. 38)
